error.notes: Dutch telecoms giant KPN has apologised for a security breach that last week forced it to suspend email access for 2 million of its customers in a dramatic and possibly unnecessary attempt to secure its systems

hacking.notes: KPN has been left severely embarrassed by events that saw a youngster access its core routers at will and its customers denied email service after a possible over-reaction

asset.notes: KPN has been left severely embarrassed by events that saw a youngster access its core routers at will and its customers denied email service after a possible over-reaction

availability.notes: Aware for some days that their servers had been hacked and fearing a serious breach, KPN's admins suspended access to the company's 2 million email accounts as a precaution

confidentiality.notes: With 2 million account holders made to change their passwords, the company found itself making an unusual public apology and offering token compensation.

discovery_notes: It is the KPN attacks that had the most dramatic effects after the details of 539 user accounts turned up on Pastebin in early February
summary: KPN has been left severely embarrassed by events that saw a youngster access its core routers at will and its customers denied email service after a possible over-reaction
